natural problem: Nine people sit down for dinner where there are three choices of meals. Three people order the beef meal, three order the chicken meal, and three order the fish meal. The waiter serves the nine meals in random order. Find the number of ways in which the waiter could serve the meal types to the nine people so that exactly one person receives the type of meal ordered by that person.
natural solution: Call a beef meal $B,$ a chicken meal $C,$ and a fish meal $F.$ Now say the nine people order meals $\text{BBBCCCFFF}$ respectively and say that the person who receives the correct meal is the first person.

We will solve for this case and then multiply by $9$ to account for the $9$ different ways in which the person to receive the correct meal could be picked. Note, this implies that the dishes are indistinguishable, though the people aren't.

For example, two people who order chicken are separate, though if they receive fish, there is only 1 way to order them. The problem we must solve is to distribute meals $\text{BBCCCFFF}$ to orders $\text{BBCCCFFF}$ with no matches.

The two people who ordered $B$'s can either both get $C$'s, both get $F$'s, or get one $C$ and one $F.$ We proceed with casework. If the two $B$ people both get $C$'s, then the three $F$ meals left to distribute must all go to the $C$ people.

The $F$ people then get $BBC$ in some order, which gives three possibilities. The indistinguishability is easier to see here, as we distribute the $F$ meals to the $C$ people, and there is only 1 way to order this, as all three meals are the same.

If the two $B$ people both get $F$'s, the situation is identical to the above and three possibilities arise. If the two $B$ people get $CF$ in some order, then the $C$ people must get $FFB$ and the $F$ people must get $CCB.$ This gives $2 \cdot 3 \cdot 3 = 18$ possibilities.
Summing across the cases we see there are $24$ possibilities, so the answer is $9 \cdot 24 = \boxed{216}$.

fixes people :: nat and beef chicken fish :: nat
assumes h0 : "people = 9"
and h1 : "beef = 3"
and h2 : "chicken = 3"
and h3 : "fish = 3"
and h4 : "random_order :: bool"
shows  "number_of_ways = 216"

theorem
fixes people :: nat and beef chicken fish :: nat
assumes h0 : "people = 9"
and h1 : "beef = 3"
and h2 : "chicken = 3"
and h3 : "fish = 3"
and h4 : "random_order :: bool"
shows  "number_of_ways = 216"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: There are 9 people, 3 of whom prefer beef, 3 prefer chicken, and 3 prefer fish. If they are arranged randomly, how many ways can they be seated? The final answer is 216.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = card {p :: 9 perm. exactly_one_fixed_point p}"
shows  "n = 216"

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = card {p :: 9 perm. exactly_one_fixed_point p}"
shows  "n = 216"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Find the number of permutations of 9 elements that have exactly one fixed point. The final answer is 216.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes num_ways :: nat
assumes h0 : "num_ways = card {p :: (nat \<Rightarrow> nat). p permutes {1..9} \<and>
  (\<exists> beef_ordered chicken_ordered fish_ordered.
    beef_ordered = {1..3} \<and> chicken_ordered = {4..6} \<and> fish_ordered = {7..9} \<and>
    (\<forall> i \<in> beef_ordered. p i \<noteq> i) \<and> (\<forall> i \<in> chicken_ordered. p i \<noteq> i) \<and>
    (\<forall> i \<in> fish_ordered. p i \<noteq> i) \<and> card {i \<in> beef_ordered. p i \<in> beef_ordered} = 1 \<and>
    card {i \<in> chicken_ordered. p i \<in> chicken_ordered} = 1 \<and>
    card {i \<in> fish_ordered. p i \<in> fish_ordered} = 1)}"
shows  "num_ways = 216"
a_2.formal solution:

theorem
fixes num_ways :: nat
assumes h0 : "num_ways = card {p :: (nat \<Rightarrow> nat). p permutes {1..9} \<and>
  (\<exists> beef_ordered chicken_ordered fish_ordered.
    beef_ordered = {1..3} \<and> chicken_ordered = {4..6} \<and> fish_ordered = {7..9} \<and>
    (\<forall> i \<in> beef_ordered. p i \<noteq> i) \<and> (\<forall> i \<in> chicken_ordered. p i \<noteq> i) \<and>
    (\<forall> i \<in> fish_ordered. p i \<noteq> i) \<and> card {i \<in> beef_ordered. p i \<in> beef_ordered} = 1 \<and>
    card {i \<in> chicken_ordered. p i \<in> chicken_ordered} = 1 \<and>
    card {i \<in> fish_ordered. p i \<in> fish_ordered} = 1)}"
shows  "num_ways = 216"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: There are 9 people at a dinner party who ordered 3 different types of dishes: beef, chicken, and fish. Each type of dish was ordered by 3 people. The waiter accidentally mixed up the orders, but he remembers that each person who ordered beef got a plate that was not beef, each person who ordered chicken got a plate that was not chicken, and each person who ordered fish got a plate that was not fish. Moreover, exactly one person from each group (beef, chicken, and fish) received a plate that matches their original order. How many ways could the waiter have mixed up the orders? The final answer is 216.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 9"
and h1 : "card {x. x \<in> {1..n} \<and> (x mod 3 = 1 \<longrightarrow> x \<in> {1,4,7})} = 1"
and h2 : "card {x. x \<in> {1..n} \<and> (x mod 3 = 2 \<longrightarrow> x \<in> {2,5,8})} = 1"
and h3 : "card {x. x \<in> {1..n} \<and> (x mod 3 = 0 \<longrightarrow> x \<in> {3,6,9})} = 1"
shows  "card {x. x \<in> {1..n} \<and> (x mod 3 = 1 \<longrightarrow> x \<in> {1,4,7}) \<and> (x mod 3 = 2 \<longrightarrow> x \<in> {2,5,8}) \<and> (x mod 3 = 0 \<longrightarrow> x \<in> {3,6,9})} = 216"

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 9"
and h1 : "card {x. x \<in> {1..n} \<and> (x mod 3 = 1 \<longrightarrow> x \<in> {1,4,7})} = 1"
and h2 : "card {x. x \<in> {1..n} \<and> (x mod 3 = 2 \<longrightarrow> x \<in> {2,5,8})} = 1"
and h3 : "card {x. x \<in> {1..n} \<and> (x mod 3 = 0 \<longrightarrow> x \<in> {3,6,9})} = 1"
shows  "card {x. x \<in> {1..n} \<and> (x mod 3 = 1 \<longrightarrow> x \<in> {1,4,7}) \<and> (x mod 3 = 2 \<longrightarrow> x \<in> {2,5,8}) \<and> (x mod 3 = 0 \<longrightarrow> x \<in> {3,6,9})} = 216"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Consider the set of natural numbers up to 9. Find the number of elements in the set that satisfy the following conditions: if the element is divisible by 3 with a remainder of 1, it must be one of {1, 4, 7}; if the element is divisible by 3 with a remainder of 2, it must be one of {2, 5, 8}; and if the element is divisible by 3 with a remainder of 0, it must be one of {3, 6, 9}. The final answer is 216.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 9"
and h1 : "3 + 3 + 3 = n"
shows  "exactly_one_correct n 3 3 3 = 216"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Nine people sit down for dinner where there are three choices of meals. Three people order the beef meal, three order the chicken meal, and three order the fish meal.  The two people who ordered $B$'s can either both get $C$'s, both get $F$'s, or get one $C$ and one $F.$ We proceed with casework. If the two $B$ people both get $C$'s, then the three $F$ meals left to distribute must all go to the $C$ people.

 If the two $B$ people both get $F$'s, the situation is identical to the above and three possibilities arise. If the two $B$ people get $CF$ in some order, then the $C$ people must get $FFB$ and the $F$ people must get $CCB.$ This gives $2 \cdot 3 \cdot 3 = 18$ possibilities.
 Summing across the cases we see there are $24$ possibilities, so the answer is $9 \cdot 24 = \boxed{216}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 9"
and h1 : "3 + 3 + 3 = n"
shows  "exactly_one_correct n 3 3 3 = 216"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: What is the result when you multiply the number of occurrences of the number 3 in the equation $3 + 3 + 3 = 9$ by the sum itself? The final answer is 216.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes num_ways :: nat
assumes h0 : "num_ways = card {f :: (nat \<Rightarrow> nat). (\<forall>n \<in> {1,2,3}. f n = n) \<and> (\<forall>n \<in> {4,5,6}. f n = n - 3) \<and> (\<forall>n \<in> {7,8,9}. f n = n - 6)}"
shows  "num_ways = 216"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Nine people sit down for dinner where there are three choices of meals. Three people order the beef meal, three order the chicken meal, and three order the fish meal. The waiter serves the nine meals in random order. Find the number of ways in which the waiter could serve the meal types to the nine people so that exactly one person receives the type of meal ordered by that person.
 The final Answer is 216
 ### Proof
 Call a beef meal $B,$ a chicken meal $C,$ and a fish meal $F.$ Now say the nine people order meals $\text{BBBCCCFFF}$ respectively and say that the person who receives the correct meal is the first person.
 We will solve for this case and then multiply by $9$ to account for the $9$ different ways in which the person to receive the correct meal could be picked. Note, this implies that the dishes are indistinguishable, though the people aren't.
 For example, two people who order chicken are separate, though if they receive fish, there is only 1 way to order them. The problem we must solve is to distribute meals $\text{BBCCCFFF}$ to orders $\text{BBCCCFFF}$ with no matches.
 The two people who ordered $B$'s can either both get $C$'s, both get $F$'s, or get one $C$ and one $F.$ We proceed with casework. If the two $B$ people both get $C$'s, then the three $F$ meals left to distribute must all go to the $C$ people.
 The $F$ people then get $BBC$ in some order, which gives three possibilities. The indistinguishability is easier to see here, as we distribute the $F$ meals to the $C$ people, and there is only 1 way to order this, as all three meals are the same.
 If the two $B$ people both get $F$'s, the situation is identical to the above and three possibilities arise. If the two $B$ people get $CF$ in some order, then the $C$ people must get $FFB$ and the $F$ people must get $CCB.$ This gives $2 \cdot 3 \cdot 3 = 18$ possibilities.
 Summing across the cases we see there are $24$ possibilities, so the answer is $9 \cdot 24 = \boxed{216}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes num_ways :: nat
assumes h0 : "num_ways = card {f :: (nat \<Rightarrow> nat). (\<forall>n \<in> {1,2,3}. f n = n) \<and> (\<forall>n \<in> {4,5,6}. f n = n - 3) \<and> (\<forall>n \<in> {7,8,9}. f n = n - 6)}"
shows  "num_ways = 216"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: In how many ways can a function $f$ be defined such that for $n \in \{1, 2, 3\}$, $f(n) = n$, for $n \in \{4, 5, 6\}$, $f(n) = n - 3$, and for $n \in \{7, 8, 9\}$, $f(n) = n - 6$? The final answer is 216.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat and count :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 9"
and h1 : "count = 3"
and h2 : "exactly_one_person_gets_correct_meal n count"
shows  "number_of_ways = 216"
a_6.formal solution:

theorem
fixes n :: nat and count :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 9"
and h1 : "count = 3"
and h2 : "exactly_one_person_gets_correct_meal n count"
shows  "number_of_ways = 216"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: In a group of 9 people, exactly one person gets the correct meal. How many ways can this occur if there are 3 different meals? The final answer is 216.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat and P :: "(nat \<times> nat) set"
assumes h0 : "n = 9"
and h1 : "P = {(beef, beef_order), (chicken, chicken_order), (fish, fish_order)}"
and h2 : "card P = 3"
and h3 : "card {(beef, beef_order)} = card {(chicken, chicken_order)} = card {(fish, fish_order)} = 3"
and h4 : "exactly_one_correct_order n P"
shows  "number_of_ways = 216"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Nine people sit down for dinner where there are three choices of meals. Three people order the beef meal, three order the chicken meal, and three order the fish meal. The waiter serves the nine meals in random order.  The two people who ordered $B$'s can either both get $C$'s, both get $F$'s, or get one $C$ and one $F.$ We proceed with casework. If the two $B$ people both get $C$'s, then the three $F$ meals left to distribute must all go to the $C$ people.

 If the two $B$ people both get $F$'s, the situation is identical to the above and three possibilities arise. If the two $B$ people get $CF$ in some order, then the $C$ people must get $FFB$ and the $F$ people must get $CCB.$ This gives $2 \cdot 3 \cdot 3 = 18$ possibilities.
 Summing across the cases we see there are $24$ possibilities, so the answer is $9 \cdot 24 = \boxed{216}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat and P :: "(nat \<times> nat) set"
assumes h0 : "n = 9"
and h1 : "P = {(beef, beef_order), (chicken, chicken_order), (fish, fish_order)}"
and h2 : "card P = 3"
and h3 : "card {(beef, beef_order)} = card {(chicken, chicken_order)} = card {(fish, fish_order)} = 3"
and h4 : "exactly_one_correct_order n P"
shows  "number_of_ways = 216"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: There are three types of dishes: beef, chicken, and fish. Each type has three orders to be served. The total number of orders is 9. Find the number of ways to arrange the orders such that only one type of dish is served in the correct order. The final answer is 216.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes count :: nat and meal_orders :: "nat list" and meal_served :: "nat list"
assumes h0 : "length meal_orders = 9"
and h1 : "length meal_served = 9"
and h2 : "count_occs meal_orders 1 = 3"
and h3 : "count_occs meal_orders 2 = 3"
and h4 : "count_occs meal_orders 3 = 3"
and h5 : "\<forall> i \<in> {0..8}. meal_orders ! i = 1 \<or> meal_orders ! i = 2 \<or> meal_orders ! i = 3"
and h6 : "\<forall> i \<in> {0..8}. meal_served ! i = 1 \<or> meal_served ! i = 2 \<or> meal_served ! i = 3"
shows  "count = 216"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Nine people sit down for dinner where there are three choices of meals. Three people order the beef meal, three order the chicken meal, and three order the fish meal. The waiter serves the nine meals in random order. Find the number of ways in which the waiter could serve the meal types to the nine people so that exactly one person receives the type of meal ordered by that person.
 The final Answer is 216
 ### Proof
 Call a beef meal $B,$ a chicken meal $C,$ and a fish meal $F.$ Now say the nine people order meals $\text{BBBCCCFFF}$ respectively and say that the person who receives the correct meal is the first person.
 We will solve for this case and then multiply by $9$ to account for the $9$ different ways in which the person to receive the correct meal could be picked. Note, this implies that the dishes are indistinguishable, though the people aren't.
 For example, two people who order chicken are separate, though if they receive fish, there is only 1 way to order them. The problem we must solve is to distribute meals $\text{BBCCCFFF}$ to orders $\text{BBCCCFFF}$ with no matches.
 The two people who ordered $B$'s can either both get $C$'s, both get $F$'s, or get one $C$ and one $F.$ We proceed with casework. If the two $B$ people both get $C$'s, then the three $F$ meals left to distribute must all go to the $C$ people.
 The $F$ people then get $BBC$ in some order, which gives three possibilities. The indistinguishability is easier to see here, as we distribute the $F$ meals to the $C$ people, and there is only 1 way to order this, as all three meals are the same.
 If the two $B$ people both get $F$'s, the situation is identical to the above and three possibilities arise. If the two $B$ people get $CF$ in some order, then the $C$ people must get $FFB$ and the $F$ people must get $CCB.$ This gives $2 \cdot 3 \cdot 3 = 18$ possibilities.
 Summing across the cases we see there are $24$ possibilities, so the answer is $9 \cdot 24 = \boxed{216}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes count :: nat and meal_orders :: "nat list" and meal_served :: "nat list"
assumes h0 : "length meal_orders = 9"
and h1 : "length meal_served = 9"
and h2 : "count_occs meal_orders 1 = 3"
and h3 : "count_occs meal_orders 2 = 3"
and h4 : "count_occs meal_orders 3 = 3"
and h5 : "\<forall> i \<in> {0..8}. meal_orders ! i = 1 \<or> meal_orders ! i = 2 \<or> meal_orders ! i = 3"
and h6 : "\<forall> i \<in> {0..8}. meal_served ! i = 1 \<or> meal_served ! i = 2 \<or> meal_served ! i = 3"
shows  "count = 216"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: In a restaurant, there are 9 meal orders and 9 meals served. The meal orders consist of 3 orders of meal 1, 3 orders of meal 2, and 3 orders of meal 3. The meals served also consist of meal 1, meal 2, and meal 3 only. How many different ways can the meals be served to match the orders? The final answer is 216.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 9"
and h1 : "3 people_order_beef"
and h2 : "3 people_order_chicken"
and h3 : "3 people_order_fish"
and h4 : "exactly_one_correct_meal = (\<lambda> n. number_of_ways_to_serve_meals n)"
shows  "exactly_one_correct_meal n = 216"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Nine people sit down for dinner where there are three choices of meals. Three people order the beef meal, three order the chicken meal, and three order the fish meal. The waiter serves the nine meals in random order. Find the number of ways in which the waiter could serve the meal types to the nine people so that exactly one person receives the type of meal ordered by that person.
 The final Answer is 216
 ### Proof
 Call a beef meal $B,$ a chicken meal $C,$ and a fish meal $F.$ Now say the nine people order meals $\text{BBBCCCFFF}$ respectively and say that the person who receives the correct meal is the first person.
 We will solve for this case and then multiply by $9$ to account for the $9$ different ways in which the person to receive the correct meal could be picked. Note, this implies that the dishes are indistinguishable, though the people aren't.
 For example, two people who order chicken are separate, though if they receive fish, there is only 1 way to order them. The problem we must solve is to distribute meals $\text{BBCCCFFF}$ to orders $\text{BBCCCFFF}$ with no matches.
 The two people who ordered $B$'s can either both get $C$'s, both get $F$'s, or get one $C$ and one $F.$ We proceed with casework. If the two $B$ people both get $C$'s, then the three $F$ meals left to distribute must all go to the $C$ people.
 The $F$ people then get $BBC$ in some order, which gives three possibilities. The indistinguishability is easier to see here, as we distribute the $F$ meals to the $C$ people, and there is only 1 way to order this, as all three meals are the same.
 If the two $B$ people both get $F$'s, the situation is identical to the above and three possibilities arise. If the two $B$ people get $CF$ in some order, then the $C$ people must get $FFB$ and the $F$ people must get $CCB.$ This gives $2 \cdot 3 \cdot 3 = 18$ possibilities.
 Summing across the cases we see there are $24$ possibilities, so the answer is $9 \cdot 24 = \boxed{216}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 9"
and h1 : "3 people_order_beef"
and h2 : "3 people_order_chicken"
and h3 : "3 people_order_fish"
and h4 : "exactly_one_correct_meal = (\<lambda> n. number_of_ways_to_serve_meals n)"
shows  "exactly_one_correct_meal n = 216"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: There are 9 people at a dinner party, and they have each pre-ordered one of three meal options: beef, chicken, or fish. There are exactly 3 people who ordered each type of meal. If the server is only able to serve exactly one correct meal to one person, find the number of ways the server could serve the meals. The final answer is 216.
